rsbNotes.title: Ezek 23
rsbNotes.text: 23:1–49 Ezekiel propounds another allegory. The two sisters are a tale of two cities: “Oholah” is Samaria, the capital of the northern kingdom, and “Oholibah” is Jerusalem, capital of the southern kingdom.

rsbNotes.title: Ezek 23:3
rsbNotes.text: 23:3 played the whore. Though Ezekiel emphasized that each individual and generation would bear responsibility for its own sin (18:1–32 note), he also describes a cumulative guilt and a deferred punishment. The indictment of the two kingdoms begins with their prostitution in Egypt (16:26; 20:5–9).

rsbNotes.title: Ezek 23:4
rsbNotes.text: 23:4 mine. The sisters had a covenant relationship with the Lord.

rsbNotes.title: Ezek 23:5
rsbNotes.text: 23:5 lovers. Israel’s oath of exclusive allegiance to the Lord would be broken by foreign alliances as well as by idolatry (vv. 5–10; 16:26 note; cf. Hos. 8:9). Prostitution did not secure the admiration or affection of the Assyrian lovers—quite the contrary (vv. 9, 10). Ultimately Assyria destroyed the northern kingdom (2 Kin. 17:5, 6).

rsbNotes.title: Ezek 23:14
rsbNotes.text: 23:14 further. Judah entered alliances of her own with the Babylonians (2 Kin. 20:12–18; 23:29; Is. 39:1). There were also overtures to Egypt (23:19–21).

rsbNotes.title: Ezek 23:23
rsbNotes.text: 23:23 Pekod and Shoa and Koa. Probably Aramean tribes east of the Tigris River.

rsbNotes.title: Ezek 23:29
rsbNotes.text: 23:29 naked and bare. See 16:35–41.

rsbNotes.title: Ezek 23:31–34
rsbNotes.text: 23:31–34 The cup is a common metaphor in the Bible. In many cases it is symbolic of God’s blessings (Ps. 16:5; 23:5; 116:13; 1 Cor. 10:16). It can also represent the anger of God (Ps. 75:7, 8; Is. 51:17–20; Jer. 25:15–29; 49:12; 51:7; Lam. 4:21; Hab. 2:16; Zech. 12:2; Rev. 14:9–11). This cup of wrath is mentioned by Jesus in the Garden of Gethsemane (Matt. 26:39, 42) and appears in John’s account of Jesus’ death (John 18:11; 19:28–30).
